content.description: Climb straight up through the small roof to the ledge. Get in some gear, and figure out the fun moves up the seam in the overhanging prow. Watch your shins: there isn't much gear in front of your face while you work out the crux, and the jagged ledge below could be a shin basher.Top out.
content.location: On the right corner of the formation, under a small roof and the overhanging prow.

content.description: Located on the front face, climb left face.  Pull small overhang (crux) then onto the top.
Climb right side of face and corner.

Route put up in spring of 2012, by myself,(Luke Bollinger) and Joe Snyder. Very solid rock, needed almost no cleaning, other than a small pine tree that was growing out of shelf near top. Route located on face to the right of 5.2 Chimney. Bouldery start leads to an early crux. Climb past shelf on left up the tallest part of the wall. Very fun movement. One of the best routes at Brown Rock.
content.protection: Small to med nuts and cams. Crux Is VERY hard to pro, hence the R rating. I used a #2 BD aid nut on the FA, (not very reliable). Rest of pro takes a little finess, but can be very solid. Cam belay from top of route, or pine tree. Easy top rope set up on pine tree, access from left or right side of cliff.

content.description: Outside corner eleven feet right of Chimney.
Start on a small outward leaning ledge just left of dead 	tree in chimney.
Climb the right side of the face.
Start at left hand corner, traverse left over roof, then up face.
Start left of hooked tree. Climb up face into the branches.

One move up to a horizontal crack, traverse around the corner bumping your hands until you arrive at the amazing vertical hands crack. Land sweet, sweet, jams all the way to the top. Last couple of feet the crack narrows to perfect hands/off fingers. 

  This can be lead or bouldered.
content.location: The start is 5ft left of Big Mama. See the photos here for helpful reference points.

content.description: Climb up the gap in the rock.

A beautiful 20ft splitter finger/off finger/thin hands crack (crack itself is very condusive to climbing, its a treat for sure) that leads into a left facing corner/roof; pull onto the face to the right (don't pull the roof rather go out onto the face in the corner, to the right); crimpy with some thin side pulls. Veer left (crux) following thin seam to obvious left facing corner and top out.
content.protection: Standard rack. Thin and creative pro (tricam...) above the crack
content.location: When crossing the boulder field heading to Brown Rocks you will be angling up and right (when facing the ridge); this climb will be at the slabby first area you come to. Once off the boulder field its the area directly in front of, or to the right of you. It sits just North/West of Brown Rocks proper (North Face Left, Five Star Crack, Big Mama, etc). You'll see this line as you come around, the entire left and right of it is lichen covered.

content.description: Start nine feet left of the north facing corner.  Climb center of face to start, midway break left for 5.8 or right for 5.9.
Start on North Face left, traverse left over the roof until you straddle the arete.  Climb up and left onto the face in the rear of the pillar.

Brown Rocks is a beautiful outcrop of brown Antietam Quartzite rock facing northwest into the Cumberland valley.  The crags are located on the northwest side of the Monalto Mountain, part of the Appalachian Mountains in Franklin County PA.  This formation can be seen off to the right or south of White Rocks. 

  Climbs at Brown Rocks are predominately single pitches, and as high as 45 feet.  All the climbs are traditionally (Trad) protected.  It is also an excellant top rope area as well.
